Since you're learning JavaScript <strong data-start="38" data-end="57">alongside React</strong>, your focus should be on the <strong data-start="87" data-end="146">core concepts that are most useful in React development</strong> — not everything, just the essentials.</p>
<hr data-start="187" data-end="190">
<h3 data-start="192" data-end="260">🔑 <strong data-start="199" data-end="260">Core JavaScript Topics to Focus On (especially for React)</strong></h3>
<h4 data-start="262" data-end="303">🧠 Fundamentals (must be rock solid)</h4>
<ul data-start="304" data-end="1000">
<li data-start="304" data-end="401">
<p data-start="306" data-end="401"><strong data-start="306" data-end="332">Variables &amp; Data Types</strong> (<code data-start="334" data-end="339">let</code>, <code data-start="341" data-end="348">const</code>, <code data-start="350" data-end="355">var</code>, strings, numbers, booleans, arrays, objects)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="402" data-end="471">
<p data-start="404" data-end="471"><strong data-start="404" data-end="417">Functions</strong> — function declarations, expressions, arrow functions</p>
</li>
<li data-start="472" data-end="564">
<p data-start="474" data-end="564"><strong data-start="474" data-end="498">Conditionals &amp; Loops</strong> — <code data-start="501" data-end="510">if/else</code>, <code data-start="512" data-end="517">for</code>, <code data-start="519" data-end="526">while</code>, <code data-start="528" data-end="537">forEach</code>, <code data-start="539" data-end="544">map</code>, <code data-start="546" data-end="554">filter</code>, <code data-start="556" data-end="564">reduce</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="565" data-end="657">
<p data-start="567" data-end="657"><strong data-start="567" data-end="590">Events &amp; DOM basics</strong> — not deeply needed in React but helps understand component events</p>
</li>
<li data-start="658" data-end="742">
<p data-start="660" data-end="742"><strong data-start="660" data-end="677">Array Methods</strong> — <code data-start="680" data-end="685">map</code>, <code data-start="687" data-end="695">filter</code>, <code data-start="697" data-end="705">reduce</code>, <code data-start="707" data-end="713">find</code>, <code data-start="715" data-end="725">includes</code>, <code data-start="727" data-end="733">some</code>, <code data-start="735" data-end="742">every</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="743" data-end="837">
<p data-start="745" data-end="837"><strong data-start="745" data-end="756">Objects</strong> — access, destructuring, nesting, <code data-start="791" data-end="802">...spread</code> operator, optional chaining (<code data-start="832" data-end="836">?.</code>)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="838" data-end="898">
<p data-start="840" data-end="898"><strong data-start="840" data-end="860">Scope &amp; Closures</strong> — especially how <code data-start="878" data-end="883">let</code>/<code data-start="884" data-end="891">const</code> behave</p>
</li>
<li data-start="899" data-end="1000">
<p data-start="901" data-end="1000"><strong data-start="901" data-end="918">ES6+ features</strong> — destructuring, arrow functions, template literals, rest/spread, <code data-start="985" data-end="1000">import/export</code></p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1002" data-end="1005">
<h3 data-start="1007" data-end="1043">🪄 JS Tricks That Help in React:</h3>

<h3 data-start="1467" data-end="1514">🔄 Suggested Learning Order (Short &amp; Sweet)</h3>
<ol data-start="1515" data-end="1822">
<li data-start="1515" data-end="1542">
<p data-start="1518" data-end="1542">Variables &amp; data types</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1543" data-end="1577">
<p data-start="1546" data-end="1577">Functions and arrow functions</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1578" data-end="1607">
<p data-start="1581" data-end="1607">Arrays and array methods</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1608" data-end="1638">
<p data-start="1611" data-end="1638">Objects and destructuring</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1639" data-end="1687">
<p data-start="1642" data-end="1687">Conditional rendering (<code data-start="1665" data-end="1669">if</code>, ternary <code data-start="1679" data-end="1684">? :</code>)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1688" data-end="1724">
<p data-start="1691" data-end="1724">Loops (<code data-start="1698" data-end="1703">for</code>, <code data-start="1705" data-end="1714">forEach</code>, <code data-start="1716" data-end="1721">map</code>)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1725" data-end="1764">
<p data-start="1728" data-end="1764">DOM basics (optional, light touch)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1765" data-end="1822">
<p data-start="1768" data-end="1822">ES6 features (<code data-start="1782" data-end="1787">...</code>, <code data-start="1789" data-end="1794">let</code>/<code data-start="1795" data-end="1802">const</code>, <code data-start="1804" data-end="1819">import/export</code>)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="1824" data-end="1827">
<h3 data-start="1829" data-end="1851">⏱ Your Time Budget</h3>
<p data-start="1852" data-end="1946">Since you're doing this in a 10-day focused plan and React is your <strong data-start="1919" data-end="1936">main priority</strong>, aim for:</p>
<ul data-start="1947" data-end="2222">
<li data-start="1947" data-end="1998">
<p data-start="1949" data-end="1998"><strong data-start="1949" data-end="1980">3–4 JavaScript sessions max</strong> (~25–30 min each)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1999" data-end="2059">
<p data-start="2001" data-end="2059">Build <strong data-start="2007" data-end="2028">small experiments</strong> — don’t just watch, code along</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2060" data-end="2222">
<p data-start="2062" data-end="2086">Example mini-projects:</p>
<ul data-start="2089" data-end="2222">
<li data-start="2089" data-end="2114">
<p data-start="2091" data-end="2114">TODO list in plain JS</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2117" data-end="2154">
<p data-start="2119" data-end="2154">Filter/search items from an array</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2157" data-end="2183">
<p data-start="2159" data-end="2183">Light/dark mode toggle</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2186" data-end="2222">
<p data-start="2188" data-end="2222">Counter app (very React-relevant!)</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="2224" data-end="2227">
<p data-start="2229" data-end="2250">Would you like me to:</p>
<ol data-start="2251" data-end="2422">
<li data-start="2251" data-end="2295">
<p data-start="2254" data-end="2295">Suggest a <strong data-start="2264" data-end="2294">video playlist or resource</strong>?</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2296" data-end="2355">
<p data-start="2299" data-end="2355">Plan out the <strong data-start="2312" data-end="2354">JS learning across the 10-day schedule</strong>?</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2356" data-end="2422">
<p data-start="2359" data-end="2422">Track what you do each day so you don’t forget what to revisit?</p>
</li>
</ol>

<h4 data-start="298" data-end="322">🧩 <strong data-start="306" data-end="322">Event Basics</strong></h4>
<ul data-start="323" data-end="489">
<li data-start="323" data-end="345">

<li data-start="346" data-end="362">
<p data-start="348" data-end="362"><code data-start="348" data-end="362">event.target</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="363" data-end="437">
<p data-start="365" data-end="437"><code data-start="365" data-end="389">event.preventDefault()</code> — <strong data-start="392" data-end="437">super useful for handling forms in React!</strong></p>

<h4 data-start="491" data-end="515">🔄 <strong data-start="499" data-end="515">Event Phases</strong></h4>
<ul data-start="516" data-end="629">
<li data-start="516" data-end="565">
<p data-start="518" data-end="565"><strong data-start="518" data-end="536">Event Bubbling</strong> (<code data-start="538" data-end="545">false</code>) – default behavior</p>
</li>

</li>
</ul>

break-words light"><p data-start="0" data-end="178">Great question, Anushila! These are two common middlewares used in backend development (especially with <strong data-start="104" data-end="118">Express.js</strong>), and they serve <strong data-start="136" data-end="177">very different but important purposes</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="180" data-end="183">
<h3 data-start="185" data-end="235">🔐 1. <strong data-start="195" data-end="235">CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)</strong></h3>
<h4 data-start="237" data-end="263">🔸 <strong data-start="245" data-end="263">Why we use it:</strong></h4>
<p data-start="264" data-end="403">To allow your frontend (usually running on a different origin like <code data-start="331" data-end="347">localhost:3000</code>) to access your backend server (like <code data-start="385" data-end="401">localhost:5000</code>).</p>
<h4 data-start="405" data-end="424">🧠 By default:</h4>
<p data-start="425" data-end="521">Browsers <strong data-start="434" data-end="452">block requests</strong> from one origin (domain + port) to another for <strong data-start="500" data-end="520">security reasons</strong>.</p>
<h4 data-start="523" data-end="549">🛠️ Example Use Case:</h4>
<p data-start="550" data-end="707">You're building a React frontend (<code data-start="584" data-end="607">http://localhost:3000</code>) and an Express backend (<code data-start="633" data-end="656">http://localhost:5000</code>).<br data-start="658" data-end="661">
Without enabling CORS, the browser will throw:</p>
<blockquote data-start="708" data-end="829">
<p data-start="710" data-end="829">❌ “Access to fetch at '<a data-start="733" data-end="758" rel="noopener" target="_new" class="" href="http://localhost:5000/api">http://localhost:5000/api</a>' from origin '<a data-start="773" data-end="794" rel="noopener" target="_new" class="" href="http://localhost:3000/">http://localhost:3000</a>' has been blocked by CORS policy.”</p>
</blockquote>
<h4 data-start="831" data-end="851">✅ How to solve:</h4>
<pre class="overflow-visible!" data-start="852" data-end="966"><div class="contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary"><div class="flex items-center <p data-start="970" data-end="1037"><code data-start="970" data-end="989">credentials: true</code> is used if you’re sending cookies/auth headers.</p>
</blockquote>
<hr data-start="1039" data-end="1042">
<h3 data-start="1044" data-end="1071">🍪 2. <strong data-start="1054" data-end="1071">cookie-parser</strong></h3>
<h4 data-start="1073" data-end="1099">🔸 <strong data-start="1081" data-end="1099">Why we use it:</strong></h4>
<p data-start="1100" data-end="1205">To <strong data-start="1103" data-end="1119">read cookies</strong> sent by the client in HTTP requests. Without it, Express can’t access cookies easily.</p>
<h4 data-start="1207" data-end="1233">🛠️ Example Use Case:</h4>
<p data-start="1234" data-end="1399">Your frontend stores a <strong data-start="1257" data-end="1274">session token</strong> or <strong data-start="1278" data-end="1285">JWT</strong> in a cookie.<br data-start="1298" data-end="1301">
When the user makes a request, the backend needs to <strong data-start="1353" data-end="1373">read that cookie</strong> to authenticate the user.</p>

<hr data-start="1644" data-end="1647">
<h3 data-start="1649" data-end="1665">🧩 Together:</h3>
<ul data-start="1666" data-end="1806">
<li data-start="1666" data-end="1747">
<p data-start="1668" data-end="1747"><strong data-start="1668" data-end="1676">CORS</strong> lets your frontend <em data-start="1696" data-end="1702">send</em> cookies to backend (via <code data-start="1727" data-end="1746">credentials: true</code>)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1748" data-end="1806">
<p data-start="1750" data-end="1806"><strong data-start="1750" data-end="1767">cookie-parser</strong> lets your backend <em data-start="1786" data-end="1792">read</em> those cookies</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1808" data-end="1811">
<h3 data-start="1813" data-end="1851">🔐 If you're using authentication:</h3>
<p data-start="1852" data-end="1878">They’re <strong data-start="1860" data-end="1873">essential</strong> for:</p>
<ul data-start="1879" data-end="1952">
<li data-start="1879" data-end="1898">
<p data-start="1881" data-end="1898"><strong data-start="1881" data-end="1898">Login systems</strong></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1899" data-end="1929">
<p data-start="1901" data-end="1929"><strong data-start="1901" data-end="1929">Session/token management</strong></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1930" data-end="1952">
<p data-start="1932" data-end="1952"><strong data-start="1932" data-end="1952">Protected routes</strong></p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1954" data-end="1957">

<h2 data-start="2526" data-end="2551">🔁 In Simple Language:</h2>
<blockquote data-start="2553" data-end="2648">
<p data-start="2555" data-end="2648">🌐 <strong data-start="2558" data-end="2566">CORS</strong> = "Hey backend, please talk to my frontend even though it’s on a different port."</p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote data-start="2650" data-end="2748">
<p data-start="2652" data-end="2748">🍪 <strong data-start="2655" data-end="2672">cookie-parser</strong> = "Hey backend, please read the cookies the browser sends with my request."</p>
</blockquote>
<hr data-start="2750" data-end="2753">
<p data-start="2755" data-end="2776">Would you like me to:</p>

</li>

<li data-start="593" data-end="637">
<p data-start="595" data-end="637">Here, <code data-start="601" data-end="607">this</code> refers to the <code data-start="622" data-end="628">user</code> object</p>
</li>
<li data-start="638" data-end="716">
<p data-start="640" data-end="716">So <code data-start="643" data-end="658">this.username</code> is the same as <code data-start="674" data-end="689">user.username</code> <strong data-start="690" data-end="716">(only in this context)</strong></p>
</li>
</ul>

<blockquote data-start="1257" data-end="1342">
<p data-start="1259" data-end="1342">If you had hardcoded <code data-start="1280" data-end="1295">user.username</code>, it would still say "Mou", which is <strong data-start="1332" data-end="1341">wrong</strong>!</p>

<p data-start="1344" data-end="1431">✅ But using <code data-start="1356" data-end="1371">this.username</code> makes the function <strong data-start="1391" data-end="1415">dynamic and reusable</strong> across objects.</p>

<p data-start="821" data-end="921">JavaScript runs <code data-start="837" data-end="853">welcomeMessage</code> <strong data-start="854" data-end="871">as a function</strong>, and it looks for a variable named <code data-start="907" data-end="917">username</code> in:</p>
<ol data-start="923" data-end="1049">
<li data-start="923" data-end="968">
<p data-start="926" data-end="968">🔎 <strong data-start="929" data-end="944">Local scope</strong> (inside the function)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="969" data-end="1026">
<p data-start="972" data-end="1026">🔎 <strong data-start="975" data-end="991">Parent scope</strong> (where the function was defined)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1027" data-end="1049">
<p data-start="1030" data-end="1049">🔎 <strong data-start="1033" data-end="1049">Global scope</strong></p>
</li>
</ol>
<p data-start="1051" data-end="1119">If it doesn’t find <code data-start="1070" data-end="1080">username</code> <strong data-start="1081" data-end="1107">in any of those places</strong>, it throws:</p>
<blockquote data-start="1120" data-end="1165">
<p data-start="1122" data-end="1165">❌ <code data-start="1124" data-end="1165">ReferenceError: username is not defined</code></p>
</blockquote>
<hr data-start="1167" data-end="1170">
<h3 data-start="1172" data-end="1216">🧠 Why you need <code data-start="1192" data-end="1207">this.username</code> instead:</h3>
<ul data-start="1218" data-end="1415">
<li data-start="1218" data-end="1271">
<p data-start="1220" data-end="1271">You're not accessing a <em data-start="1243" data-end="1253">variable</em> called <code data-start="1261" data-end="1271">username</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1272" data-end="1334">
<p data-start="1274" data-end="1334">You're accessing a <em data-start="1293" data-end="1303">property</em> of an object (<code data-start="1318" data-end="1333">user.username</code>)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1335" data-end="1415">
<p data-start="1337" data-end="1415">And inside the method, <code data-start="1360" data-end="1366">this</code> refers to the <strong data-start="1381" data-end="1406">object that called it</strong> → <code data-start="1409" data-end="1415">user</code></p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1417" data-end="1420">So:</p>
<pre class="overflow-visible!" data-start="1421" data-end="1544"><div class="contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary"><div class="flex items-center That’s awesome, Anushila 😄🎉<br data-start="36" data-end="39">
You just wrapped your head around one of the most <strong data-start="89" data-end="115">misunderstood concepts</strong> in JavaScript — the difference between <strong data-start="155" data-end="164">scope</strong> and <strong data-start="169" data-end="196">object context (<code data-start="187" data-end="193">this</code>)</strong>. That’s a big win! 🧠💥</p>
<hr data-start="222" data-end="225">
<h3 data-start="227" data-end="269">🔁 Quick Recap You Can Remember Later:</h3>
<ul data-start="271" data-end="477">
<li data-start="271" data-end="323">
<p data-start="273" data-end="323"><code data-start="273" data-end="283">username</code> is not a variable — it’s a <strong data-start="311" data-end="323">property</strong></p>
</li>
<li data-start="324" data-end="390">
<p data-start="326" data-end="390">You can’t access it directly like a variable inside the function</p>
</li>
<li data-start="391" data-end="477">
<p data-start="393" data-end="477">You use <code data-start="401" data-end="416">this.username</code> because <code data-start="425" data-end="431">this</code> points to the <strong data-start="446" data-end="477">object calling the function</strong></p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="479" data-end="508">And now it <em data-start="490" data-end="498">clicks</em> for you ✨</p>
<hr data-start="510" data-end="513">
<p data-start="515" data-end="674">If you ever feel confused again about <code data-start="553" data-end="559">this</code> in different contexts (like arrow functions, setTimeouts, event handlers), just ask — it evolves as you go deeper!</p>

<h2 data-start="113" data-end="157">🔁 <strong data-start="119" data-end="157">JavaScript <code data-start="132" data-end="138">this</code> – Quick Revision</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="159" data-end="223">✅ Why can’t we just use <code data-start="187" data-end="197">username</code> inside the object method?</h3>
<ul data-start="224" data-end="402">
<li data-start="224" data-end="279">
<p data-start="226" data-end="279">Because <code data-start="234" data-end="244">username</code> is a <strong data-start="250" data-end="262">property</strong>, not a variable.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="280" data-end="327">
<p data-start="282" data-end="327">It’s not in the <strong data-start="298" data-end="326">function’s lexical scope</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="328" data-end="402">
<p data-start="330" data-end="402">Using just <code data-start="341" data-end="351">username</code> gives: ❌ <code data-start="361" data-end="402">ReferenceError: username is not defined</code></p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="404" data-end="407">
<h3 data-start="409" data-end="445">✅ Why do we use <code data-start="429" data-end="444">this.username</code>?</h3>
<ul data-start="446" data-end="622">
<li data-start="446" data-end="509">
<p data-start="448" data-end="509"><code data-start="448" data-end="454">this</code> refers to the <strong data-start="469" data-end="479">object</strong> that is calling the function.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="510" data-end="570">
<p data-start="512" data-end="570">So <code data-start="515" data-end="530">this.username</code> accesses the correct value dynamically.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="571" data-end="622">
<p data-start="573" data-end="622">Works even if method is reused in another object.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<blockquote data-start="254" data-end="380">

Instead, they <strong data-start="324" data-end="379">inherit <code data-start="334" data-end="340">this</code> from the surrounding (lexical) scope</strong>.</p>
</blockquote>

class="hljs-keyword">const</span></span><span> user = {
  </span><span><span class="hljs-attr">name</span></span><span>: </span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Anushila"</span></span><span>,

  </span><span><span class="hljs-attr">normalFn</span></span><span>: </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span></span><span> (</span><span><span class="hljs-params"></span></span><span>) {
    </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">console</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-title function_">log</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Normal:"</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">this</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-property">name</span></span><span>); </span><span><span class="hljs-comment">// ✅ "Anushila"</span></span><span>
  },

  </span><span><span class="hljs-attr">arrowFn</span></span><span>: </span><span><span class="hljs-function">() =&gt;</span></span><span> {
    </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">console</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-title function_">log</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Arrow:"</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">this</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-property">name</span></span><span>); </span><span><span class="hljs-comment">// ❌ undefined</span></span><span>
  }
};

user.</span><span><span class="hljs-title function_">normalFn</span></span><span>(); </span><span><span class="hljs-comment">// ✅ this → user object</span></span><span>
user.</span><span><span class="hljs-title function_">arrowFn</span></span><span>();  </span><span><span class="hljs-comment">// ❌ this → global object (or undefined in strict mode)</span></span><span>
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<h3 data-start="1125" data-end="1158">Why does <code data-start="1138" data-end="1147">arrowFn</code> fail here?</h3>
<p data-start="1159" data-end="1391">Because it's defined <strong data-start="1180" data-end="1200">inside an object</strong>, but not with a proper method syntax. Arrow functions don’t bind <code data-start="1266" data-end="1272">this</code>, so <code data-start="1277" data-end="1283">this</code> comes from the <strong data-start="1299" data-end="1314">outer scope</strong> — which is the global context (<code data-start="1346" data-end="1354">window</code> in browsers), not the <code data-start="1377" data-end="1383">user</code> object.</p>
<hr data-start="1393" data-end="1396">

<p data-start="1612" data-end="1751">✅ This works because the arrow function inside <code data-start="1659" data-end="1671">setTimeout</code> <strong data-start="1672" data-end="1706">inherits <code data-start="1683" data-end="1689">this</code> from <code data-start="1695" data-end="1704">greet()</code></strong>, which is a normal function bound to <code data-start="1744" data-end="1750">user</code>.</p>

Let’s explain <strong data-start="72" data-end="79">why</strong> <code data-start="80" data-end="86">this</code> doesn't work in arrow functions <strong data-start="119" data-end="135">step by step</strong>, visually and intuitively.</p>
<hr data-start="164" data-end="167">
<h2 data-start="169" data-end="197">🧠 First: What is <code data-start="190" data-end="196">this</code>?</h2>
<p data-start="199" data-end="301">In JavaScript, <code data-start="214" data-end="220">this</code> is a special keyword that refers to <strong data-start="257" data-end="300">the object that is calling the function</strong>.</p>
<ul data-start="303" data-end="547">
<li data-start="303" data-end="405">
<p data-start="305" data-end="405">In <strong data-start="308" data-end="328">normal functions</strong>, <code data-start="330" data-end="336">this</code> is <strong data-start="340" data-end="351">dynamic</strong> — it changes depending on how the function is called.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="406" data-end="547">
<p data-start="408" data-end="547">In <strong data-start="411" data-end="430">arrow functions</strong>, <code data-start="432" data-end="438">this</code> is <strong data-start="442" data-end="453">lexical</strong> — it comes from the <strong data-start="474" data-end="525">surrounding code where the function was defined</strong>, not how it's called.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="549" data-end="552">
<h2 data-start="554" data-end="597">📸 Imagine This Scene (Visual Metaphor):</h2>
<h3 data-start="599" data-end="635">Let's say you're inside a house:</h3>
<h3 data-start="637" data-end="664">🏠 <strong data-start="644" data-end="663">Normal Function</strong>:</h3>
<p data-start="665" data-end="733">When someone calls you (runs the function), you look around and say:</p>
<blockquote data-start="734" data-end="799">
<p data-start="736" data-end="799">“Okay, <strong data-start="743" data-end="765">who is calling me?</strong> That’s who I belong to (<code data-start="790" data-end="796">this</code>).”</p>
</blockquote>

<h3 data-start="1004" data-end="1031">🛩️ <strong data-start="1012" data-end="1030">Arrow Function</strong>:</h3>

<blockquote data-start="1133" data-end="1214">
<p data-start="1135" data-end="1214">“I don’t care who calls me. I belong to <strong data-start="1175" data-end="1195">where I was born</strong>, not who uses me.”</p>

<p data-start="1346" data-end="1362">⛔ Why undefined?</p>
<ul data-start="1363" data-end="1616">
<li data-start="1363" data-end="1571">
<p data-start="1365" data-end="1571">Because the arrow function <code data-start="1392" data-end="1399">speak</code> was defined inside the <code data-start="1423" data-end="1430">house</code> object, but its <code data-start="1447" data-end="1453">this</code> <strong data-start="1454" data-end="1493">was captured from the outside scope</strong> — which is likely the global object (<code data-start="1531" data-end="1539">window</code> or <code data-start="1543" data-end="1554">undefined</code> in strict mode).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1572" data-end="1616">
<p data-start="1574" data-end="1616">It does <strong data-start="1582" data-end="1615">not bind <code data-start="1593" data-end="1599">this</code> to the object</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>

class="hljs-keyword">function</span></span><span> </span><span><span class="hljs-title function_">User</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-params"></span></span><span>) {
  </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">this</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-property">name</span></span><span> = </span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Anushila"</span></span><span>;

  </span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">setTimeout</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span></span><span> (</span><span><span class="hljs-params"></span></span><span>) {
    </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">console</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-title function_">log</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Normal:"</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">this</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-property">name</span></span><span>); </span><span><span class="hljs-comment">// ❌ undefined</span></span><span>
  }, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1000</span></span><span>);

  </span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">setTimeout</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-function">() =&gt;</span></span><span> {
    </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">console</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-title function_">log</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Arrow:"</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-variable language_">this</span></span><span>.</span><span><span class="hljs-property">name</span></span><span>); </span><span><span class="hljs-comment">// ✅ Anushila</span></span><span>
  }, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1000</span></span><span>);
}

</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">new</span></span><span> </span><span><span class="hljs-title class_">User</span></span><span>();
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<h3 data-start="1894" data-end="1902">Why?</h3>
<ul data-start="1904" data-end="2136">
<li data-start="1904" data-end="2032">
<p data-start="1906" data-end="2032">The normal function inside <code data-start="1933" data-end="1945">setTimeout</code> is called by the system (<code data-start="1971" data-end="1979">window</code>), not by the User object → <code data-start="2007" data-end="2018">this.name</code> is undefined.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2033" data-end="2136">
<p data-start="2035" data-end="2136">The arrow function captures <code data-start="2063" data-end="2069">this</code> from the <code data-start="2079" data-end="2085">User</code> constructor → so it correctly prints <code data-start="2123" data-end="2135">"Anushila"</code>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
